title: 114_s1030
content: The Act titled "Aaron's Law Act of 2015" clarifies that "access without authorization" in Section 1030 of Title 18, United States Code, refers to circumventing technological barriers to gain unauthorized access. The Act "Aaron's Law Act of 2015" amends Section 1030 of Title 18, United States Code, to define "access without authorization" as obtaining information on a protected computer without permission by circumventing technological or physical barriers. The Act "Aaron's Law Act of 2015" defines "access without authorization" as obtaining information on a protected computer without permission by circumventing technological or physical barriers. It removes the term "exceeds authorized access" from the law. SEC. 3. ELIMINATING REDUNDANCY. Section 1030(a) of title 18, United States Code is amended by repealing paragraph (4) and redesignating paragraphs (5), (6), and (7) as paragraphs (4), (5), and (6) respectively. Conforming amendments are made in subsection (c) by updating references from (a)(6) to (a)(5) and from (a)(4) or (a)(7) to (a)(6). Amendments are made in subsection (c) to update references from (a)(6) to (a)(5) and from (a)(4) or (a)(7) to (a)(6). Subparagraphs in paragraph (4) are updated by replacing references from (a)(5) with (a)(4). Subsection (c) is amended to update references from (a)(6) to (a)(5) and from (a)(4) or (a)(7) to (a)(6). Subparagraphs in paragraph (4) are updated by replacing references from (a)(5) with (a)(4). Additionally, subsection (h) is amended by replacing references from (a)(5) with (a)(4). SEC. 4. MAKING PENALTIES PROPORTIONAL TO CRIMES. Section 1030(c)(2) of title 18, United States Code is amended to include changes related to financial gain and criminal acts in violation of laws. The amendments to Section 1030(c)(2) of title 18, United States Code include changes related to financial gain and criminal acts, such as prohibiting certain acts and specifying fair market value. Additionally, adjustments are made to subparagraph (C) by replacing "conviction for another" with "subsequent" and inserting "such" after "attempt to commit".
